Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from two fragments, with 1924,1201.1272, and added plaster) of South Ionian pottery little master cup; interior: on rim, trace of dilute lines between bands; glazed black on body; accidental drip on rim; top of rim glazed; exterior: myrtle leaf band with row of added white dots; band at top of handle zone which is reserved; lower wall glazed with reserved area at break.
Type series: Schlotzhauer little master Ionian Cup type
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1924,1201.1272. Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, the decorative pattern and the curved junction of the rim and body find parallels with his South Ionian little master cups and South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9B. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type XI (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116). These cups have been found in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Hayes suggested a Rhodian origin for these types of cups but this is uncertain (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 114). Schlotzhauer points out that the same myrtle pattern is found on Fikellura style pottery from Miletus and thus suggest a South Ionian or more specifically Milesian origin for the cups (Schlotzhauer 2012, 108-9).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.814) (Phase 3)
